bibl.title: Letter from Luis B. Pogolotti to Philip Showalter Hench, September 30, 1940

div1.p: Pogolotti replies to Hench's questions concerning place names and locations, and traces the history of the ownership of the land where Camp Lazear was located.

div1.head: Letter from Luis B. Pogolotti to Philip Showalter Hench, September 30, 1940
div1.opener:
Havana, Cuba.
Sept. 30, 1940.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
In reply to your letter of August 26th, please note
the following:
Paragraph 6:
The tent Camp Columbia was erected immediately after
the arrival of the Seventh Division of the U.S. Army on Dec. 15,
1898. The site was a farm. There is no exact date available as
to the wooden barracks erected but construction was started imme-
diately after the soldiers were lodged in tents. The wooden bar-
racks were torn down in 1936 and 1937 by the present army headed
by Colonel Fulgencio Batista, Chief of Staff at that time.
Paragraph 7:
Quemados is a sub-division of the town of Marianao,
I never heard of a public library in Marianao and there are no
maps of the town.
Paragraph 32:
The present Military City is about 10 acres. May I
point out that Col. Fulgencio Batista, Chief of Staff, and strong-
man of the Island, resigned last November to run for President
and was elected. He will take office Oct. 10th next. Colonel
José Pedraza is now Chief of Staff.
You are right about Calzada de los Quemados, which
ends in front of the Hospital and is where General Lee Street
begins.
In your directions how to get to the false site of
Camp Lazear, please note the changes of direction beginning with
the word “Turning northwest.” This should read “Turning southeast
off Calzada de Columbia at the eastern (or southeastern) entrance
of Military City, we traversed the (approximately) southern rim
of the grounds bounded by Calzada de los Quemados (and General Lee
Street) passing on our right the Military Hospital.” Then this
should read: At the end of Calzada de Columbia we turned into
General Lee Street for one block and then going south on Santa
Rosa Street down to the railroad crossed the railroad and turned
west for a block on a mud road." The part beginning with the word
“Proceeding” and ending with “railroad” in the same sentence is
wrong. Forget about Boquetta Road as you did not travel on it,
-2-
you were on Santa Rosa Street and possibly were at the corner of
Boquetta Road, which is unpaved, when you asked where you were,
since Boquetta Road crosses Santa Rosa Street.
I am enclosing a plan of the Military Hospital marked
“Hospital Aristides Agramonte - Finca La Soledad.” The Hospital
is known the “Aristides Agramonte” Hospital or the Military Hospital,
since March 1935. The “Fourth of September Clinic” was built in
1930-31 but was never finished. After the revolution on Sept. 4,
1933 it was completed and named “Fourth of September Clinic”. You
will note on the plan and the attached slip of paper that each
building is specified.
The Carnino Station was erected in 1930.
Linea Paradero - “Linea” is commonly used for railroad
altho it is really “linea de ferrocarril”. Paradero is the word
used for railway station.
Paragraph 35:
Correct except that the houses you mention are not
cement but brick and lumber.
Paragraphs 38th and 39th:
My brother came from New York with the American Inter-
vention as a civil employee. He bought the property August 1914
from the Dominican Fathers before the Notary Raul Galletti of
Marianao, in whose portocol the original documents are filed. The
Dominican Fathers obtained it from Father Zamora, a member of the
Dominican Fathers, who left it to them as part of his estate.
Paragraph 53:
In this paragraph you state “he and his brother”. It
was my brother who made this transaction and I was not concerned
in same. My brother purchased San José from Señora Maria Teresa Loma
y Navarrete on Dec. 17, 1910 under Deed No. 331 before the Notary
Dr. Jacinto Pedroso. This deed was clarified by another document
before the same Notary on January 20, 1911, Document No. 16, both
original documents being filed in the protocol of this Notary.
My brother, Dino Francisco Pogolotti, purchased 347,576 sq. meters.
the Señora reserving 25,000 sq. meters as her present residence.
On Oct. 4, 1919 my brother sold two lots to Rafecas
Macia y Cia. under Document No. 335 before the Notary Dr. Carlos
Alzugaray. One of 68,813 sq. meters bounded on the North by
the Brick factory and Streetf Luis Valdes, on the South by the
Sugar Mill Toledo, on the East by the tillable land belonging to
Pedroso - Acosta, and on the West by Blooks 22, 20, 12 and Pasaje.
The other lot on which the brick factory is located composed of
62,743 sq. meters, fronting on the Calzada, on the rear by Block
-3-
13, part 12 and 22, on the right by land of Acosta - Pedroso and
on the left by Blook 22. The rest of the land he made into a
sub-division.
“Tejar” means a small brick yard. There is a brick
yard and quarry operated by two separate companies. The quarry
existed for many years, probably being worked in the Spanish days,
and it was probably operating when my brother purchased it. I
don't know.
Paragraph 54:
There is no Avenida de Consulado, it is Avenida de
Buen Retiro. Directions correct until you reached Calzada de
Marianao. At that point you turned left on the Calzada toward
Havana going about 8 or 10 blocks to Calle Jose Miguel Gomez on
which the estate is located. You did not pass a brick factory.
All the rest is correct except the concrete fence. This is a stone
fence.
Paragraph 58:
We did not built this house.
Paragraph 67:
I am returning your Photo No. 2 with a few notes
answering your questions on the back of the picture as follows:
1. Neither one as it is an unnamed street.
2. The house should be more east as I have marked.
3. It is correct.
4. Yes, I think so.
5. The last date of 1918 was printed on the map
after the Municipality of Marianao had named several streets and
a new copy of the map was issued showing names of said streets.
There are three new units marked A B C on your photo at the Military
Hospital - “Aristides Agramonte Hospital”. One is the tuberculosis,
the other is infectious diseases and the other X-Ray.
I am also returning your Photo 5 on which I have
marked the route you took to the false Camp with red pencil and
the route to the real site at San Jose in blue pencil.

I trust that I have answered all the above to your
satisfaction. If you require more explanation on any of them I
shall be delighted to do everything possible.
